awd_titl_txt: Comprehensive Study of the Most Pristine Objects Known in the Outer Solar System
awd_abstract_narration:
The Solar System objects that formed farthest away from the Sun and remained in these locations are also the objects least changed over the long period of time since they were formed.  They likely still keep clues to the conditions at the time of the formation of the Solar System.  These conditions could also be present in other planetary systems.  These astronomers will observe about 50 of these objects over the life of the study to learn about the characteristics of the objects, including their shape, the rate they spin, their coloring, and whether two objects formed close enough to touch each other.  Telescopes in Arizona and Chile will be used in the study.  This project serves the national interest as it increases our scientific knowledge about the most pristine objects in the Solar System.  The Principal Investigator's home institution, Lowell Observatory, will include the results in their public outreach programs, which reach well over 100,000 people per year.

The investigators will conduct a comprehensive observational study of the dynamically Cold Classical (CC) trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs) to understand their formation, evolution, composition, and rotational properties.  They will build an extensive data set of visible images for astrometry, lightcurve, color, and binary object study.  These data will be used as tracers of the formation and evolution of this pristine population.  They will regularly use the 4.3-m Discovery Channel Telescope and the 6.5-m Magellan Telescope and plan to include several NOAO facilities in case of interesting targets.  Cold Classical objects with a visual magnitude up to 23.5 - 24 mag in all size ranges will be targeted, with priority given to objects that are potentially contact binaries.  The investigators plan to characterize 15 - 20 CCs per year, resulting in a sample of about 50 objects at the end of the project.  By studying these most pristine objects in the Solar System, the investigators will determine primordial constraints crucially needed to understand the entire TNO population, and, by extension, the formation and evolution of both our own Solar System and other planetary systems.  Results from the research will be incorporated into Lowell Observatory outreach programs including the visitor center which receives about 100,000 visitors every year, as well as the "Meet An Astronomer" and the "Navajo-Hopi outreach" programs.

por.por_cntn:
The trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs, or Kuiper belt objects) are the least evolved small bodies in our Solar System. They are leftovers from the formation and evolution of the early Solar System and provide a window to the era of planetesimal and planet formation. Our project focused on a specific sub-population in the trans-Neptunian belt; the dynamically Cold Classical TNOs which are not affected by mean motion resonance with Neptune, have never suffered a strong collisional history, were formed roughly where they exist today and have remained far from the Sun, so their surfaces have not undergone significant thermal evolution compared to the other TNOs. The dynamically Cold Classical TNOs are thought to be the most primordial small bodies in our Solar System, and so, by studying them we have access to the early conditions of the Solar System.

We carried out a comprehensive survey of the rotational and physical properties of the dynamically Cold Classical TNOs with the 4.3m Lowell Discovery Telescope (LDT) and the 6.5m Magellan-Baade Telescope. We increased by ~320% the number of Cold Classical TNOs with a lightcurve study demonstrating that these objects tend to rotate slower and are more deformed/elongated that the other TNOs. We also used our survey to give context to the second flyby of NASA?s New Horizons spacecraft by comparing the Cold Classical TNO named Arrokoth to the rest of the Cold Classical population. Before the flyby and based on our survey, we inferred that Arrokoth would be a slow rotator with a deformed shape, and both predictions were confirmed by the flyby.

An interesting characteristic of Arrokoth is its contact binary nature. The definition of contact binary includes objects with a peanut shape or bilobed shape, two objects touching in one point and thus in contact, and two objects with a small separation. Unfortunately, no contact binary was discovered in the Cold Classical population to compare Arrokoth to. Therefore, part of our project was to discover and characterize contact binaries in the Cold Classical population. Our survey discovered four contact binaries, and we have inferred that there is a deficit of contact binaries in this population with a fraction of about 10-25%. Contact binaries found in the Cold Classical population have an ultra-red surface which is characteristic of this population and also suggests that they were formed in-situ. We extended our search of contact binaries and found one in the 2:1 mean motion resonance with Neptune and four in the 3:2 mean motion resonance with Neptune. We discovered that most of the contact binaries trapped in these mean motion resonances with Neptune have a very red/ultra-red surface which links them to the dynamically Cold Classical population, and we considered them as escaped Cold Classical. We estimated that there is an excess of contact binaries in the 3:2 mean motion resonance with Neptune with up to 50% of contact binaries and a deficit in the 2:1 mean motion resonance with a fraction of 7-14% which is comparable to the one in the Cold Classical population.

So far, our project has produced five peer-reviewed publications with additional papers in preparation and two chapters for the Trans-Neptunian Solar System book. One student was trained to detect, identify and obtain the photometry and astrometry of serendipitously detected small bodies during our observations. Twelve students were mentored to develop a software to model the lightcurve of binary/multiple systems. In addition, our work was presented to scientific communities during meetings and conferences and to the general audience.
